newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austria says CA sale to Bank Austria only option.
newsitem.headline: Austria says CA sale to Bank Austria only option.

text.p: The Austrian government said on Tuesday the hotly-contested sale of Creditanstalt to the country's biggest bank, Bank Austria, was the only possible option to end the seven-year privatisation process.

The government of Chancellor Franz Vranitzky's Social Democrats and Foreign Minister Wolfgang Schuessel's conservatives struck a last-minute deal at the weekend on the privatisation after a row over the buyer had split the coalition.

Vranitzky told a special session of parliament that the agreement was the "biggest economic decision in Austria's recent history", adding there had been no alternative to Bank Austria since the market leader had made the best offer for the state's 70 percent voting stake in Creditanstalt.
"We have sold to the highest bidder. Everything else would have been unthinkable, not just in terms of the state budget," Vranitzky said.
Creditanstalt's privatisation has dragged on for seven years.

In the final stages the conservatives had baulked at a sale to Bank Austria, openly preferring a rival bid from an international group led by insurer EA-Generali, and threatened to team up with the far-right opposition Freedom Party of Joerg Haider in parliament to block the agreement.
Haider said the conservatives had missed a historic chance to remove political influence from Austria's banking system.
Bank Austria is effectively controlled by the Social Democrat-led City of Vienna. According to the deal, the bank will be taken out of public control step by step over the next seven years.

"This could have been a great hour for Austria's economic renewal," Haider said, directing his comments at Schuessel. "But you didn't have the power to see it through. You have become the laughing stock of Austria."
Schuessel won concessions from the Social Democrats in the deal, including a buyout of small Creditanstalt shareholders by Bank Austria and a job guarantee for Creditanstalt employees.

He told parliament the conservatives remained worried about Bank Austria's ability to finance the purchase price of 17.2 billion schillings ($1.54 billion) out of its capital resources without threatening its own financial health.
"The agreement wasn't easy for us. But we will do everything we can to make this story a success story," he said.

"It is up to the new owners of Creditanstalt to prove that they care about more than just shareholder value," Schuessel added. "One thing is clear: The most important thing in the banking world is not capital, but the people who work there and the customers who bring their money." ($1=11.15 Schilling)
